SPLENDID

HIT!!

of the New Grand Mythological Burlesque Extravaganza, called

THE JUDGMENT
OF PARISi
OB,

THE

PAS

tZT—XtMmiLjL l L IL-I'LLH

A SEW burlesque, called the Judgment of Paris, has been
produced at this then Ire, chiefly for the purpose of introducing a
parody on the Pas des Dresses' by Messrs. Wright, (Venus) Paul
Bedford (Juno), and Ryan (Minerva). Wright's imitation of
Taglioni's step and Cento's manner is excellent; and the business
of bouquet-ibrowing is comically caricatured, the bouquets being
finally tJiken off in a wheelbarrow by a Utile winged divinity.
Bedford's '* variation'' is a strange movement to tbe tune of
" J o l l y Nose," and Ryan's an Irish jig. The wise en scene is
exceedingly pretty.and the first appearance of the three goddesses,
each in a separate tableau, exhibited through an aperture hi the
'flat,' is .effectively managed in imitation of* tbe po»es plastkpws.'
The burlesque is perfectly successful.— Times, August 19, 1846.
The Judgment of Parts t or, the Pas de Pi/ipins. This is a
mythological blvetle, intended as a burlesque on the Pas de
Ddesses, which has excited so frenetic an enthusiasm at Her
Majesty's Theatre. Taglioni, Cerito, and Lucile Grahn are
impersonated by Wright, Bedford, and Redmond Ryan. There
is much matter, however, proceeding the chorcgraphie variations
which give the title t o tbe extravaganza. Jupiter tMr. Selby)
gives a soiree to the several gods and goddesses that flourish in
Lernp iere, and they luxuriate in sh»try cobbler and various
other caithly luxuries, j roving that all that is pleasant to the eye
and agreeable to the taste are the gifts of the gods. These serve
us convenient media whereon to work ad caplandum jokes and
gooJ-humourod hits at the ruling follies; »ud in these Ml.
Charles Selbv, the author, has been entiiely successful. The
three danseutes ttfss for their first v.ui.tion, which fans to the
lot of Minerva, who, gifted with nn Ir.sh brogue, thereupon
indulges in nn Irish jig, accompanied by the national howl; then
came Bedford wiTi ' N i x my Doll/,'' and essayed divers
pirouettes;
then Wright. Bushels of bouquets were rained
down, and were removed by Mercury in a wheelbarrow. There
are some excellent parodies, and the scenery is beautiful. We
must not, in justice, pass uncommended the sweet warbling of
.Mis* Miinan 'laylor, who enacted Psyche. The play bill, describing the qualities of the characters, is no unaorthy pendant to
Gilbert ii B-cket's Comic Blackstono.—Morning Post,

upon the popular dhertissemei.t which bus lately excited so much

August 18, 1816'.
A trloiious burlesque (from the prolific pen of Selby, on i f
Judgment de Paris, and Le Pas des Deesses, has been produced at the Adelphi under the title of The Judgment, of
Paris, or, The Pas de Pippins.
The getting up is magnificent, the scenery and costumes splendid, and tins bcrlesque
itself full of bioud fv.n. Ryui. Puul Bedi'oid, and Wright are
the three goddesses. Glorious n u t , as Juno, appeals riding on
a peacock, and is ttimed round a hi Aellers on a pedestal, the
spread tail of the peacock uppeniing as thougli it were part of
Juno's piopcr peison : and \» rigl t, as Venus, rises from the sea,
after the most approved fashion. The Pas de Pippins was superbj
\ . right's imitation cf Tnghoui was close, and at the same
time most ludicrous, lie was encored as a matter of course, and
l.i« mincing aid tlee.'*e-like manner of advancing towards the
.piihesiia, f.ii the purpose of directing ibe conductor when and
where to te-commeme the music, was rich caricature, and
elicited tours of laughter. Then the bouquets were showered in
Mich prolusion that Mercury was obliged to gather them up, and
trundle them iff in a wheelbarrow, and at the conclusion there
was a second shower, which the goddesses gathered into their
aprons. The costumes weio grotesquely classical. The bill of
laic for the supper of the gods—furnished by ."-'oyer of course—
was full of fun. Some of the best jokes, however, were too
reehet-eM for tbe audience; for instance, Alouettes (Larks)
II hi Hhferfari, pass d unnoticed. The dances are admirably
arranged; and some of them, the dance of the hotlris for
instance, exceedingly euweiuf; undone or two beautiful melodies are iMrcdiiccd,\vhieii arc tastefully sung by Miss Marian
Taylor. This burlesque is a palpable hit—as great a hit as the
original Tha House was crowded to suffocation, and will continue io be so every night that the Judyitit-n? of Paris is acted
lor months to come.—Hun.
Tin: celebrity which ttie last New Ballet, The Judgment of
1'itu'x, obtained ut the Opeia-honse has, as a matter of course,
• ailed forth >i distorted, though laughable reflection of the
beautiful original at the AdelphfTheatre. on Monday. Aug. 17th,
iii the form of a burlesque, which Was attended with complete
sue cess. The Judgment of Part* is a really brilliant affair, and
is an excellent parody on the .esthetic grace "of the ballet at the
Opcia-house. Can anything be imagined more hidicrotisly absuid
ilnm the substitution of Paul Btitfonl, Wright, and Rvnn for
l.ucile Umbo. Ovriio. and Tajrtioni, in the characters «i Juno,
V.iiUs, and Minerva <. The arrival of the thiee geddoses at tbe
t*vasl given by Jupiter on tit. marriage irf IVJcits and Thetis was
1 vecedingly effectitre ; roarsof Innghiei f.,!lowed the preseutatioa

HE

of the rival Olympians, as they successively appeared in the centre
of an expanding star on a revolving platform, which exhibited
them in all their phases. Paul Bedford's Juno was prodigiously
funny, and remarkably broad; he was encored in his first sons',
which he gave with great comic effect. Mr. Wright's triumph
was in the Pas de Pippins—a parody on the celebrated Pas des
Deesses—where his admirable burlesque of the choregraphic style
of the queen of the ballet elicited immense applause. Minerva was
played by Mr. Ryan with a rich Irish brogue, which she confesses
she caught in Kerry by drinking whisky in mistake for sherry; he
sung- a very good parody,wbich was encored, but his Irish jig, in the
Pa* de Pippins was perhaps the best feature iirhis performance.
The great thunderer himself was personated by Mr. Selbv (the
author of the burlesque). From the nature of the piece, depending on its laughftblo situations for success, it scarcely comes
within the scope of literary criticism ; the fun is broad and mixed
up with some smart hits and humorous allusions at the passing
topic?* of the time, which told well with the audience. The music
has been selected with great taste—it is popular and catching;
the scenery by Messrs. Pitt and Johnstone, beautiful; and the
whole mise en scene and costumes, equal to anything produced at
this Theatre, which the public now recognise as an establishment
where the.s matters- are directed by the nicest taste and the
utmost liberality.-— Sunday Times.
ENCOURAGED by the success of bis 'Mazourkaphobia,' Selbv
has now burlesqued the ballet of * The Judgment of Paris?
Wright, Paul Bedford, and Ryan enact the three competitors for
the pippin. Tbe dialogue involves good points; and if the author
could have rn.de sure of justice being done to his composition
by the erratic gentlemen w%o delight the gods and pitites at the
Adelphi with their improvisations, we dare say he would have
been mor 1 liberal of good jokes, and more care'ful of his versification. The scenery and dances are exceedingly good.—Court
Journal, Aug. 22.
HOWEVER we may have felt a| the celebrated Pas des Di-esses,
at the Italian Opera-house, we are, of course, not insensible to the
winning graces and exquisite delicacy of the renowned danseuses,
Paul Bedford and Wrignt. .We were delighted to see them display
their surprising powers on Monday last, when was produced a
grand burlesque e.xtrauigauza, entitled the Judgment of Paris ;
or, The Pas de Pippins, by Charles Selby. This is an atnustnjr
piece,.full of puns and bem wots, quite palatable to the audience.
Wright rises from the ocean, and steps out of an oyster-shell,
and, we need hardly say, what a perfect represenlative he is of
the goddess, ! enter ,• he kept the house in roars of laughter by bis
dancing, which was embellished with the most appropriate grimace and gesture. This is, ceitaiftly, a house for a good laugh.
In burlesque, and broad farce, l!u company is otimalled, and had
ample scope afforded them to exhibit their "talent in this new extravtgawM. The scenic decorations and costumes were excellent.
We predict a long and successful run to the Pas de Pippins.

Dispatch.
T H E sensation produced within and beyond the fashionable
world by the new ballet at the Opera,and its unapproachable quadrup!e;«n. has heenndwilly turned to account by our indefatigable
friend, Charles Selby,in a well-written and well-ordered burlesque,
which achieved a regular " A d e l p h i " triumph,under the title oi'
The Judgment of Paris, or The Pas de Pippins..and has since
tilled the house nightly. The pippins invoked by the author to go
it on this occasion, are Messrs. Bedford, Wright, and Ryan, A ,
lespeetively sustain the characters (altered from Lemptiere) 01'
Juno, Vents, and Minerva, They are all good ones to go, and
exceeding •' rum'' to look at. T be toe of the great Paul is not so
light as fantastic, but the expression of Mr. Ryan's, and the birdlike grace of Mr. Wright's, amply atone for the unavoidable infirmity. Juno on her peacock, and Venus new risen 1'tom the sea.
are tremendous things in their way—to be had in remembrance
and commended to provincial cousins. 1 be whole affair is splendidly
got up, and deseives its success almost as much for the expense
which has been liberally and judiciously gone to in its production,
as for the excellent fooling, neat parodies, and telling jokes densou
and wri'ten by the author, who, we should not omit to add. lends
ti band, in bis own pleasant, gentlemanly snle, as Jupiter. Mrs.
F rants Matthews deserves very honourable mention for her capital
treatment of a slight sketch of a shrew (Uxnone), and Miss Chap,
tin enacts Mercury with light-footed grace and vivacity. Mr. O.
Smith's " make up" as Paris, is a line bit of carieature—stipeibU
ridiculous. Mr. Selby's fun, in short, has been throughout most
effectively embodied, and, (as he is not quite a child) he rray be
safely set dow n for a ran.—-Belt's Life, August 22.
A T B I K M ; has been produced at the Adelphi. It is called the
Judgment of Pari', and is a burlesque upon the divertissement
lately produced at the Opera. Dancing and puns are its staple
commodity.—Atlas, Aug. 22.

" A little shop, quite crammed and choked with the abundance of its slock; a perfectly voracious little shop, with a maw as accommodating and full as any shark's. Cheese, butter, firewood, soap, pickles, matches, bacon, table beer, peg-tops, sweetmeats, boys' kites, bird
.eed, Aid ham, birch brooms, hearth-stones, rait, vinegar, blacking, red herrings, stationery, lard, mushroom catsup, stay-lace., loaves of
•read, shuttlecocks, eggs, and slate pencil; everything was fish that came to the net of this greedy little shop, and all these articles were in
its net." The dying lodger—Mrs. I'ugby's humanity—Tnghy and the till.

T E M P L E o f F L O R A S A GRAND TABLEAU OF CHARACTERS,
Or, A HUNDRED YEARS AGO.

!

R I V E R .

" Follow her ! To desperation ! To the rolling river, swift and dim, where Winter Night sat brooding like the last dark thoughts of
many who had sought a refuge there before her. Where scattered lights upon the banks gleamed sullen, red, and dull, as torches that
were burning there, to show the way to Death. Where no abode of living people cast its shadow, on the deep, impenetrable, melancholy
shade." Trotty's last lesson leaint from the creature dearest to his heart. " I know that our inheritance is held in store for us by Time.
I know there is a sea of Time to rise one day, before which all who wrong us or oppress us will be swept away like leaves. I see it. on the
flow ! j I know that we must trust and hope, and neither doubt ourselves, nor doubt the good in one enoiher. I have learnt it from the 10
creature dearest to my heart. I clasp her in my arms again. Oh ! Spirits merciful and good, I am grateful."

by Mr. Mrs. and Master Cockney—Black Servant, Mr. Teapot—Passengers, Messrs. Gadabont, Spendthrift, Sec, & . J |

"They were old Chimes, trust m*. Centuries ago, these Bells had been baptized by Bishops : so many centuries, ago, that the register
of their baptism was lost long, long before the memory of man ; and no one knew their names. They bad had their sliver mugs no doubt,
besides but time had mowed down their sponsors,and Henry the Eighth had melted down their mugs: and they now hung, nameless and mug.
less, in the Church Towtr. Not speechless, though. Far from it j I Trotty's place of business—Meg and the hot dinner —The grace
—A love story—Lectures on political economy and practical philosophy—Their consequences—Trotty's doubts of the fitness of things.

This Drama is founded on a tale by Prosper Merim^e. hwpe&eur GenSfal des Monumens Hisioriques of France, im.-l is k.te,.4e<t accurately t o depict Coraicau

• habits customs, national Character, and social peculiarities. The poople are like the Italians, hot, revengeful, quick in their sentiment*, and sanguinary in their
remembrance of injuries/ »nd unlike the French, they are grave, «obir, tsamtBt, and moody. Family feuds, and litigious schemes, are common amonjjrt the
Corsica!* in further aggravation of those dissensions which ate inseparable from the existence, in such communities, of castez aad parties.

1

On which the piece is founded, is taken from the pages of Henrich Heine, a German Author, whose " e l e g a n t and fecile p e n " ; has
enriched the world with a host of romantic bluettes, which, unfortunately for the British Public, being written in the language of
Faderland, have, notwithstanding the cheap fares to the Rhine, and Monsieur Ollendorf's six months system, escaped the rifles of
our dramatic sharp-shooters. •« The W I L I S , " says Herr Heine, " are young maidens, who, being- betrothed, die before their wedding
day, and are supposed to find no rest in the tomb ! for though life is fled, there remains in them an insatiable lore for the dance. A t
midnight, and in the bright moonlight, they rise in crowds, arrayed in their bridal dresses, wreathed with flowers and sparkling1 w i t h
jewelsytheir faces, though pale, hare the beauty of youth, and winning smiles play upon their lips. Wbe to the young man w h o s .
evil destiny leads him within the reach of their perfidious jfe.cination ! He is compelled to join their wild orgies, and to dance Vltt.
from exhaustion, he sinks down and expires.

Lord, & c , " the Corps de Ballet, will, as the sun is'shining brightly, and their employer has given them a half-holiday, express
their happiness in a

COUNT WHIRLIGIG,

—

—

Mr. W R I G H T ,

An eccentric young Nobleman, has, when out shooting, accidentally seen a pretty vounggirl called
GISELLE,
—
—
M A D A M E
C E L E S T E ,
He has of course fallen desperately in lore with her, as all eccentric young noblemen hare done from time immemorial; but
knowing the extreme shyness of the village maiden towards town gallants, he disguises himself a> a troubadour, and being1 a
pupil of Lablache and Mario, seeks to win her heart by his music*! abilititu ; but, alas < lis has a rival, a certain
ALBERT BROWN,

W O O L G A R ,
Has eclipsed him—he, Couht Whirligig-, enters the Vineyard in search of his beloved, but Hiding her not, he gives vent to his

B O N A N C E ,

HERR KAUFMAN,

Mr. S T O K E R ,
And a parly of Huntsmen, Messrs. H O R T O N , WILLIAMSON, F K E E B 0 R N , SANDERS, HUSK, CONRAN, MORGAN,
W A Y E , and ALDRIDGE, who are seeking for their master, the before-mentioned Albert e-rown, who is no other than Dake
Albert, another Grand Seigneur, who ha* al>o, for the same purpose as Count Whirligig, put on a peasant's frock, and assumedan alias—the hunters explain their mission in a R E C I T A T I V E
A n d C H O R U S , a n d pursue their search
further afield. Duke Albert then enters, attired in a costume befitting his exalted rank; but, as he poetically observes, fearing <{(
t h a t " Bond Street clothes would fritrhten his timid fair, who thinks him nothing but a farming blade," he retires into a bower
to change his dress—in the mean time. Giselle, who has hastened from her home to meet him, according' to appointment, enters,
and finding she i» the first at the rendezvous, is rather impatient and angry, but consoles herself with dancing a new

CHARACTERS :
A famous Monarch of the U.known Ages,
Whose name has been left out of M«gnall's pages,*
Two discontented Relatives.—You'll see
Their types in each—p'rhaps, your own—family,"
A gallant, young, love-making, fighting Swell;
Like .those of whom Crimean annals tell,
His little Bijother, who, by friends ignor'd,
Came on tlio Woods and Forests for his board,
His serran:^ N.B.—Not the one we know,
Who quitted Jersey a few days ago,
Called the Green Knight; but not a'lens can 'spy
The least trace of that color in his eye.
Not a great p u t ; but, in the pieoe before ye,
Essential to th, progress of the story,
A branch of that Westphalian family.
Whose members at Morel's we sometimes see,
It's needless to observe, this (airy £1/
Can be no other party but himself.
J A Prineess'fair—so brave, she too might say,

T h e Drunkard's Children, n e g l e c t e d by their p a r e n t s , e d u c a t e d only In t h e streets,
and falling into t h e bands of w r e t c h e s who live upon t h e vices of others, t h e y are
led to t h e Gin Shop, to drink a t t h a t Fountain which nourishes every speeies of crime.

B o e r Shop t h e Boy Thief squanders and Gambles a w a y b i s ill-gotten gains—The
ennning Boy is d e g g . d by far m o r . canning man.

OFPLATE III.

Shop, t h e poor Girl is drawn to t h a t conic* which ends in miserv.

O F PLATE IV.

robbery ; - h e is t a k e n by t h e Police a t a T h r e e p e n n y Lodging House.

Part II—T HE OLD BAILEY.

p a r t for ever in this world.

<>f the Surrey, Astley's, Marylebone, besides twenty Country Pantomimes,
is it to be wondered at, he would take care <>f himself. From the literal
patronage attending bis efforts last Season, lie resoleed to call to bit aid
ins Worthy Partner, M r . J . J O H R £ K > N , w h » , agisted bv M « . . r f t ,

which foe, beauty «f construction, suihenajfi Mechanical Changes and

8^- The Theatre will t»e Open Every Evenlnr.
To morrtw, a COMEDY OF SHAKSPERE'8 With a NEW FARCE.

A separate Entrance and Corridor have been appropriated t o
the D R E S S C I R C L E , in which Chairs have been placed in lien
of Benches* and Ladies and Gentlemen taking; Tickets for
this part of the T h e a t r e , W I L L H A T E T H E I R S E A T S
R E S E R V E D for

T H E W H O L E OF T H E EVENING.
Corresponding; attention will be found to have
been paid to the comfort and accommodation of t h e Public
IN T H E O T H E R CIRCLES OF BOXES, FROM T H E
CHANDELIERS OF WHICH, T H E GAS HAS BEEN
E N T I R E L Y REMOVED, ANDW A X CANDLES
SUBSTITUTED.
In compliance with the suggestions of many of
h e r Patrons, Madame V E S T R I S has the honor to announce,
that i t i s her intention to appropriate ONE E V E N I N G I N
E A C H W E E K to the performance of those Entertainments.
which for so many years have constituted the attraction of the
OLYMPIC T H E A T R E .

THE FIRST OLYMPIC NIGHT
WILL BE

On S A T U R D A Y , O C T O B E R .5th.
THE PARTICULARS OF WHICH WILL BE DULY ANNOUNCED.

Boon to be opened at half-past Six—The Performances to commence at Seven o'clock..

Box-Office, from Ten fill Four, where SEASON TICKETS may bt
had upon application.

THE FOLLOWING NEW ARRANGEMENTS
Have been made for the Season.

A separate Entrance and Corridor have been appropriated to
the D R E S S C I R C L E , in which Chairs have been placed In lien
of Benches, and Ladies and Gentlemen taking Tickets for
this part of the Theatre, W I L L H A V E T H E I R S E A T S
R E S E t t V E D for

T H E W H O L E OF T H E EVENING.
Corresponding attention will be fonnd to have
been paid to the comfort and accommodation of the Public
IN T H E O T H E R C I R C L E S O F B O X E S . FROM T H E
C H A N D E L I E R S OF W H I C H , T H E G A S H A S B E E N
E N T I R E L Y REMOVED. AND WAX CANDLES
SUBSTITUTED.

her Patrons. Madame Y E S T R I S has the honor to announce,
that It is her intention to appropriate ONE E V E N I N G I N
EACH W E E K to the performance of those Entertainments,
which for so many years have constituted the attraction of the

1h

On MONDAY, March 4 1844,
(The first

of the kind, ever given in this Country ) .

M. J U L L I E N begs leave most respectfully to acquaint the Nobility and Gentry, that he will have the honor, for the first time t i n . ,
hi. residence in this country, to give a GRAND BAL MASQUE, to take place on MONDAY, MARCH 4th, 1844.
M. JULLIEN'S long connection with the Grand Ball* at Paris being well known to many of the English Aristocraey, he has frequently
been lolicited to present one of those splendid and indeed unrivalled Entertainments to the London Fashionable World; but the want of
sufficient ipace in the buildings of which he has hitherto had the control, being an insurmountable obstacle, he has not been able to comply
with those wishes. Immediately, however, on M. J U L L I E N becoming Lessee of the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, he commenced making
the necessary arrangements for one of these fascinating soirees, disposing the general decoration arid fitting up of the Theatre accordingly, »o
as to form an area, which, when thrown open on the Ball Night, will it is thought be pronounced unequalled by any Sail* dt Danse in Europ*.
M. J U L L I E N trusts that his long experience in conducting the Balls of the Grand Opera at Paris, will be a sufficient guarantee
for the excellence, in every respect, of the one here announced, and that he will be enabled to produce such an entertainment as will not only
meet with general approbation, but also one which will become a favourite with the Nobility and Gentry of this country.
The Orchestra will consist of SEVENTY PERFORMERS and be composed of first-rate Artistes, (being the same as on th«
Concert Nights).

CONDUCTED BY M. JULLIEN.
TIUKBTf/or

Mhe Jlil.M..

lOs.Od.

Each,

To be obtained at the Box-office of the Theatre; of Mr. Mitchell, 33, Old Bond Street; and of Mr, Sams, St. James's Street.

F U L L P A J t T I e U L A I l . f i wiU be Published IJXf D I E C O U R S E ? this cart*
Announcement being merelw made with a vietv to afford sufficlmnt Time, for Visitor 8
to arrange their Parties and Costumes.
Mr. NATHAN, of No. 18, Castle Street, Leicester Square, (who has just returned from Paris, with a large selection of New Fancy
Dresses), is appointed COSTUMIER to the BALL, of whom Tickets may be obtained.
A Ball of this kind being a most interesting and brilliant spectacle, M. Jullien intends to devote the "audience portions of the
Theatre to the accommodation of those Ladies and Gentlemen who wish to be mere spectators of the gay scene, those parts being entirely
unconnected with the Salle de Dante.

M»rices of Admission

for Spectators

t—

Dress Circle, 5*.; Boxes, St.; Fi»t Gallery, 2*.; Second Gallery, 1«.
Private Boxes and Places may be secured of Mr. REILLY, at the Box-office of the Theatre; of Mr. MITCHELL, 33, Old Bond Street; of Mr. SAMS
St, James's Street; and at Mows. JULLIEN's Office, 3, Maddox Street, Bond Street.

The "Great Wizard of the JVorth"

W h o has succeeded in arranging with the Directors of the Royal Italian Opera for
this the noblest Theatre in theMetropolis, during a SHORT SEASON of a fewWeeks only.
O n W E D N E S D A Y , Dec. 26th, will be produced the Great National, Historical
and Chivalric Pantomime of Y e

^tUfitlliiHiirf

HARLEQUIN GOOD HUMOUR
AND YE

o*

BEING A

LEGEND OF THE MEETING OF THL IOIARCHS" I t w a s a marvellous s w e e t e a n d g o o d l y , s i g h t , t . see those t w o P r i n c e s , in t h . flower, of t h e i r ag«, i n t h . h e i g h t
of t h . i r s t r e n g t h * , a n d in t h e dignitie of t h e i r m a n l y e beaut ye. commanding t w o g i <sate N a t i o n s , t h a t h a d e b e e n so
long rivals a n d e n n e m i e s , i n s t e a d , of leading hostile a r m i e s to desolate a n d d e s t r o y . , m e e t i n t h a t peaceful v a l l e y .
a n d embrace l i k e b r o t h e r s , i n t h . s i g h t , of t h e choice nobilitie of e i t h e r land."—Th* Chroniclers.
'

T h e Pantomime will be produced on a scale of unexampled Splendour, outrivalling
all former displays at this Theatre when in the Zenith of its Pantomimic F a m e .
E v e r y Department has been entrusted to the most jompetent Artists.
T h e N e w a n d Elaborately Gorgeous S c e n e r y painted hy a n d u n d e r t h e
s u p e r i n t e n d e n c e of

Mr. WILLIAM

BEVERLEY,

Assisted hy Messrs. C U T H B E H T , SH ALDERS, C. ADAMS and W . GLOVER.
T h e P a n t o m i m e invented, a r r a n g e d , and produced hy

Mr. A. HARRIS.

With the same attention to Scenery, Cestume and Effects, which has characterised the productions of RTGOLETTO, I I TROVATORE
L'ETOILE DU NORD, and the various Operas lately produced at this, the recognized chief Theatre in Europe for Spectacular display!

F r a n c i s I-—(Next door neighbour of the aforesaid Henry VIII, No. 1, Westminster, but who himseif " did'nt quite live in Westminster " for an obvious
reason—" he lived t'other side of the water." A monarch of the same age as Henry, and nearly of the same size; joint author (with Henry VIII.)
of the original plot of the gorgeous drama—Wt Utile STOiartre—now represented for the first tims in a complete state on the Theatre of European
Politics. A monarch with a hooked nose, who, in consequence always looks sharp)

H e is, nevertheless, the reverse of Soporific,
being particularly wide awake. H e is one of the three lovers alluded to. who does not happen to he a king, and takes his measures accordingly)—

Last Nights before Whitsuntide.
The Lessee has great pleasure in stating that the growing attraction of the Grand
Easter Spectacle of The

together with the urgent recommendation from all quarters that it should be continued, has induced him to make such arrangements as will meet the general
wish, and supersede, for the present, the necessity of closing the Theatre.
R e v i v a l of SOPHOCLES' Classical T r a g e d y o f

The Manager begs to inform the Public that he has yielded to the general solicitation
which demands the revival of this beautiful Greek Play, and it will be produced on
WEDNESDAY, MAY 1st, with New Scenery, Dresses, and Appointments, and all

S O P H O C L E S ' Lyrical Tragedy of

This Tragedy was presented at the Theatre, in Athens, more than 2,000 years a # o , and was produced' (for the first tiaie on the
British Stage) at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, January 2nd, 1845, with

T H E CELEBRATED
C H O R U S S E i
By Dr.FELIX MENDELSSOHN BERTHOLDY
Adapted to the Modern Stage by W. BARTHOLOMEW, Esq.
In the ancient Greek Theatre the scene was fixed, and was used for all plays, indiscriminately. In order to DO' t
audience the relative positions of the actors, they entered and left the stage by the same door. The kine or Drinc I t H'*
entered by the centre, called the Royal door. The second character by a smaller door on the right hand side • " ntf tl*' t " j
characters by a small door on the left. A t the extremities of the scenes were two doors—that on the right leadint * ,1 * •through which citizens, &c , entered j and that on the left leading to the country, for strangers, messengers and such hh C?r£'
Choruses, orchestra, bacchanals, &c., were below the stage. The Greek plays having been written with a view to this a
m
the ancient Greek mode has been adapted to the modern theatre, as far as the same was practicable • and the Sta
***Sement>

decree which proved so fatal to his family.

Theatre Royal. Brlfrf/

GRAMD NATIONAL OPERA HOUSE.
THE Public is respectfully apprised, that the opportunity which has long
been considered so important to the advancement of music, on the English Stage,
is at length arrived; and the Lessee gladly avails himself thereof to make known
his intentions of carrying out a measure, which it has always been his anxious
desire to promote.
The performances recently terminated at this Theatre were, from circumstances beyond the control of the Lessee, of a general character—which tended
materially to retard the progress of any specific object; but his efforts henceforth
will be directed to the furtherance of such entertainments as are} exclusively of
an operatic nature. By the diminution of expenditure on the one hand, he will
be enabled to strengthen, even beyond their present limits, the musical resources
of this Establishment, and thereby give a more perfect representation of such
productions than has hitherto been the case.
As there can* be no question relative to the growing taste for a cultivation of music, the Lessee has further determined to place the power of this
enjoyment within the means of all classes of society, by such a reduction in the
scale of admission, as will meet the general expression of public opinion.
In a determination, therefore, to giv%

INCREASED ATTRACTIOH, AT REDUCED PRICES,
the Lessee begs to submit an outline" of his plans. The nightly entertainment
will in future consist of a Full Opera, with either an incidental Divertis«eiSii6«..t,
or ofl€T to be performed after the Opera, or, occasionally, with a Musical
Afterpiece: and the performances will be so arranged, as to commence at halfpast Seven, and to terminate about Eleven; and the following

DECISIVE REDUCTION OF PRICES

Arranged and Produced under the .Direction of Mad* LOUISE
The Music Selected and Composed by Mr. ISAACSON

L a Comtesse.

THE DESCRIPTION OF THE GRAND CORONATION EGYPTIAN PROCESSION
ARRANGED AND ADAPTED TO THE STAGE, BY " D Y K W Y l f K Y N , "
From the WorKs of C I E M B N S , HKKOBOTUS, STRABO, PLUTARCH, DIODOKUS, SICULUS, JABLOUSKI, LEPSIUS, DENEN, C H A N P O U P N ,

ROSELUKI, SAVARY, WILKINSON, and other AutlmriUei in the British

MILITARY ENTREE.

IDOLATROUS

PROCESSION.

NOTE.—"Every City, Month, Day, and Hour had its Presiding Genius."
Singer with the
Horus Copus, with
Book of " Hermes."
Palm Branch & Hour Glass.
"THE
HIEROGRAMMAT,
Or, Sacred Scribe.
(In his band the Book, Ruler, Papyrus, and Palette.)
Two FUNCTIONARIES with EMBLEMS of" POWER'' and "STABILITV."

Ho. 1. THE ABK OB-"SABINE OF XNOTJMIS.''
(Called also
"Knoum," "Neph,'" or "Num," e.i. "Water..")
The primary
form of " Aramon," and styled «' The Leader of Gods"—" The
Creative Intelligence"—" The Spirit of God"—" The Spirit of the
(Vernal) Deity''—"The Soul of the Sun"—and, by the Greeks,
* Jupiter Cbnumis.''
" Worshipped by the inhabitants of Thebais" (Plutarch).
The Asp was sacred to this God.
The Ark, (bearing his hieroglyph, with that of the Beetle or " Creative
power,") is decorated with this emblem.
Symbolic standard of ditto.
Symbolic standard of " Athor"
(Venus), the oracle of Night
or Darknes (? chaos), "from
whence arose all created things"
(Egyptian belief).
THE SYBIL, bearing the emblematic rush wand, with " Heka," The
Fryg" (the son of" Num"), and type of the first state of man.
Ho. 2, " MA," " MEI," or '* T.HJ.rEI," or " Truth," " the Blind Goddess,"
Goddess," represented with her eyes closed, or blinded.
The Priests bearing this Goddess have libation buckets and simpula,
"THMEI," or TRUTH cr JUSTICE. This deity had also a twofold
character, as Goddess of Truth and Justice. A small image of this God was
worn by the Chief Judge while engaged in listening to cases brought
before him.
A similar emblem was worn by the High Priests of the Jews, and it is
remarkable that tha word " Thummim" is not only translated " Truth;" but
being a plural or dual word, corresponds to the Egyptian word of " Ivo
Truths"—i. e. " Light and Truth." Breastplates having the figure, of the
two Gods " Re," (Light) and " Thmei," (Truth) represented upon them have
been discovered.
PRIESTS WITH SCARAB*!.

The Scarabeus may be considered as an emblem of " The Sun"—of " The
Creative power,"—and of the God " Pthah," (Vulcan).
INCENSE BEARER,

Waving his incense patera before the God. The incense was in the shape
of a small globe or pill; «nd, upon modern analyses, was found to Consist of
aromatic substances with gum, and gave out colored light or flame when
thrown into the b.rning cup.
Ho. 3. "APIS." H i . titles in hieroglyphs were " The Sacred Bull of
Memphis," " The Bull of Abundance, adored by the People," "The
Sacred Bull of Pthah," "Guardian of the Solar Year," "Api,
renowned over the World," " The Symbol of Inundation."
Richly draped, and on a car led by Priests bearing the emblems of
"Serapis," or "Sari Api," "The Pillar of Mensuration"—"Column of
Measurement," or " Nilometer," of wood divided into cubits.
Attendant Priests also fan the Idol, and offer homage as it passes forward.
The festivals in honor of Apis lasted 7 days, on which occasion a large
concourse of people assembled at Memphis—the Priests led the Sacred
(living) Ball in solemn procession, every one coming forward from their
houses to welcome him.
Pliny and Solinus affirm that children who smelt his breath were thought
thereby gifted with the power of predicting future events.
The tokens which distinguiihed this sacred Bull at his birth were a white
spot resembling a crescent on its right side, and a lump under its tongue in
the form of a Beetle—as pretended by tbe Priests. The people believe him
to be the cause of the swelling and inundation of the Nile, which produced
fertility and abundance, and celebrated his festival at about the period of
this annual ocrurrence, with every demonstration of rejoicing and literal
abandonment to the intoxication of jov all over the kingdom.
N.B.—The decorations of the drapery upon the Bull and carriage are
rincipally composed of the first flowers that spring from the earth after the
pecession of the flood, «'.«. the Lotus and Meliolotus.
PRIESTS WITH THE "PRETENDED" GOD "CANOPU,," OR WATER OFFERIM.
t o THE GOD or THE NILE.

" It is said, that the Chaldeans, transporting the fire, which was their
God, into all tbe provinces, offered to let him combat with those of other
nations, on condition that if he remained the conqueror they should adore
him. The Priests of Canopus accepted the challenge, and devised this
stratagem:—They fabricate in Egypt pitchers of an extremely porous earth,
through which the water filtrates and is purified. The Arch-Priest took one
of them, stopped tbe pores with wax, and painting it of various colors, filled
it with water, and made it his God. He covered it with the head of an
ancient statue, said to be that of the pilot Menelaus. The Chaldeans presented themselves; the contest began, they lighted their fire around the vase,
the wax melts, the water runs through the pores and extinguishes the fire;
the fraud of the Priest gave the victory to Canopus over the Chaldean deity.
From that moment his image has been represented with very short feet, a
narrow neck, and the belly and back rounded like a pitcher. It is under
this form that lie is worshipped as the vanquisher of all the Gods."—Bvffin
ffistaire de t'JEglise, livre second.
Ho. 4. THE GODDESS "PASH-T." "The Memphian Lioness," "The
beloved of Pthah," " The Goddess of Fire," "Bubastes," (the Diana
of the Greeks), preceded by sacred dancers. The Idol, carried by
Priests in their leopard-skin drewes, with red incense flaming
before her, and .surrounded by " Symbolic Divinities," " Winged
Geniuses." &c.
One of the principal festivals held in Egypt was at Bobaates, in honor of
Pash-t—700,000 persons of both sexes being present. A great number of
victims were sacrificed, wine was profusely drank, dancing of the wildest
character went forward, men played flutes, women sang and shrieked as loud
as possible, struck the"CrotoIa" (Cymbals) or Clapper, of wood and metal, &c,
Lotus DANCER, (FEMALES.)
INCENSE BEARERS.

Museum.

So. 5. THE GOD " OSIRIS." as " Osiris Pethempamentes" (the Pluto
of the Greeks)," He who is Resident in the Hades," " President
of the Amenti," " Receiver and Giver," " The Sun," " The Eye
of the World," " T h e Source of the Nile," " H e who has many
Eyes," a form of Amnion, wearing the " Atf," and having the Crook
and fiagellum. Regarded as " The authoi of time," from the word.
" Osoh-Iri," •' The maker of time."
The principal office of this Deity was to Judge the Dead, and to mle over
that kingdom where the seals of good men were admitted to eternal
felicity.
This Deity was very famous, his Temples and Priests were to be found in
almost every part of Egypt, the sacred rites of Osiris were a profound mystery,
never revealed. His name even avoided, as of too august a nature to be
mentioned.
Tbe "Ivy," with which the Priests deccrated themselves, was sacred to
him, and also the " Meltolotus."
Ho. 8. THE SACKED BOAT OF THE AMEHTI, or Lower B-giona,
with the Four Genii, or Demi-Gods (bearing emblems of Life and
Power) and their vases of " Amenti," or that subterraneous region
where they (the Egyptians) imagined the souls of the dead to go after
their decease.
The 1st genius is " Amset," " Judge of the Amenti." (Human headed.)
The 2nd is " Hepi," " Concea'ed Number." (Baboon-headed.)
The 3rd is " Tuautmutf," " Adorer of his Mother." (Jackall-headed.)
- The 4th is " Kabh-senuf," " Refresher of his Brethren." (Hawk-headed.)
The Sepulchral Vases have heads in shape of the Four Genii of the Dead,
and each was employed for holding a portion of the Visera of the deceased,
embalmed separately and deposited in them. On the " Amset" Vase i,
inscribed the speech of " Isis to the dead j on that of " Hepi'' is a similar
speech from " Nepthys;" on that of " Tuautmutf," one from " Neith;" and
on that of " Kabh-senuff," one from " Selk." The purport of each being an
Assurance of Protection, and of being " near thee," " beside thee," or " I
come to be beside thee,"
The Sacred Boat is followed by the symbolic " Eyes of Osiris," or, of " The
Sun," emblems of the all-seeing presence of tbe Divinity.
NOTE.—Besides the Four Amenti, there were 42 Assessors or Judges of
the Forty-two Crimes, from which a good man should be free, and these also
differ from the 36 Demons mentioned by Origon, that presided over the
human body, and were invoked to cure the infirmities of the peculiar member immediately under their protection.
Ho. 7, THE GODDESS "ISIS," or, "The Seat" The hieroglyphic
Throne on her head, and followed by the Priestesses and Virgins dedicated to her worship, tsis was styled also " The Beginning," (as
her sister " Nenlhys'' was " The End" and "Isis, Queen of Egypt,"
'* The Goddassof ih;- Moon," " Defender of her Brother," &c. (The
" Ceres' of the Greeks.)
The festival, says Herodotus, which they celebrate at Busoris in honor of
Isis, is magnifir cnt. After prayers a Bull is sacrificed, which th* Priests cut
up and afterwards burn, pouring oil on the fire while the victim is consuming.
Kneeling and striking them»elves in honor of" Osiris," they afterward, eat
what remains of the sacrifice.
TAMARISK DANCERS.

Ho, 8. THE GOD "HORU8," or (Khoas-Horns).—The Apollo of the
Greeks. In hieroglyph " The Warmth of the San," " The Path," (of
the Sun) " The Support," a " Defender of his Father," &c. the son of
Osiris and Isis.
He is represented with the single mystic lock of Hair of Childhood, slaying
his evil Geniuses, under the forms of the Lion, the Gazelle, Scorpions,
Vipers, &c, while Typho, Typhon, Seth or Baal, " The Evil Spirit," is esca.
ping from beneath his feet in the shape of a Crocodile.
He is attended by his sacred emblems and standards. The Hawk was
dedicated to him, the Tamarisk tree, the Testudo, (Lyre) Ac, Ac.
One of the principal duties of " Horus" was that of introducing the soul, of
the dead into the presence of " Osiris," afier they had passed the ordeal of
final judgment; he also assisted "Amset" in weighing and ascertaining their
good conduct during life, previous to their admission into the august presence
of hi. Father in the blessed region, of the Amenti.
INCENSE BEARERS.

Ho. 9. THE GODDESS "HEPTHYS" ("Proserpine" of the Greeks),
called also " The End," " The Sister Goddess," « The Saviour Sister
Goddess," " The Barren," '• Rectrix of the Lower Regions." On her
head the hieroglyphic emblem of her name, a bowl and basket called
" Neb," placed upon a house, answering to " E i " or " Tei"—" Nebtei" or " Neb-thy," " The Lady of the Abode."
" The Sistrnm, having the face of Isis on one side, and Nepthys on the
other, symbolically represents 'the Beginning' and' the End,' or 'Generation and Corruption.'"—Plutarch.
Ho. 10. THE GODDESS "HEITH," (the "Minerva" of the Greeks.) Enthroned, with sceptre, aud wearing the "Teshr." Preceded by
Musicians, male and female, Bearers of Incense with green flame,
and surrounded by symbolic Divinities.
*' Neith " was styled " The Mother Goddess," or " Mother of God, "—
"The* Deified personification of Air" (Diodorus). She presided over the
Upper Hemisphere, and was particularly worshipped at Sais. Stringed
Musical Instruments (the Bouni, or Harp of 17 strings, especially) were
dedicated to her. " Neith " or " Neth,",is the supposed origin of the Greek
name, " Thena " or " AtHena."
The belief of the Egyptians in " the Existence of a Supreme Being," i,
proved by the inscription over the Temple of Minerva (Neith), in hieroglyphic
characters, viz.—" I am that which is, which was, and shall be. No Mbrtai
has lifted up my veil—the offspring of my power is the sun; and the
Immortality of the Soul." By the prayer recited at the tim, of death, by
an Egyptian expressing his desire to be received into the presence of the
deities.
SYMBOLS OK MAU AND TEFND, AND JEGIS or ATHOE.

Ho. 11. " MEBSEKAB," the Snake Goddess, called also " Melsigor " or
" Mersokar "—" Ruler of the Lower Regions."
Ho. 13. THE GBEAT GOD "A-MMOH;' or "Hammon," "Amen,
"Amen-ra," "Amoun," " The King of Gods," " T h e Concealed,'
"The Hidden," "The Intellectual Sun." Wearing on his head
the " Tesher," surmounted by the Disc and Plumes. In his right
hand the " Tau," or Emblem of Life, and in his left the " Gora," or
Sceptre of Power.
A large Altar of Burning Incense is carried before him; on either side
are his symbols of " Creative power," the Sacred Ureus, or Serpent of
Amtnon,—Priests with crooks and fans, in their habits and insignia of the
highest order, with the Mgis of the God—" The Intellectual Sun "—containing the symbolic " All-seeing Eyes," " The Divine Scarabeus," and
the Ram-head|d God, "Chnoumis," the vernal creative intelligence or
divinity.
THE KING AMD QUEEN CROWSED.
The King bears in his haud tbe sceptre of " Truth, jwstice, and Mercy."
The Queen, that of the "Sovereinty of the Nile." They are preceded by
Dancers and Musicians, Ladies and Officers of the Con*, and Household ;
the God '• Etetbyia," or sacred vulture, " The Protectress of Kings "—
" The Pure," borne immediately in front of the royal personages; the
State Flabella, behind and over their heads, together with the Banners of
Nitocris and Egypt, flanked by the royal cwkhs—tWfchs of - Re " (the Sun);
sacred symbols, with various insignia, royal aad military standards, &c, Ac.

PRESo

SPECTACLE,

THE DAILY NEWS, Oct 6th.

The MORNING HERALD, Oct 9th.

Mr. E . T . Smith has commenced his winter session
at this theatre under more enterprising circumstances
than hitherto, and the arrangements he has made
betoken a desire to pursue a more legitimate course,
though without conceding the principle of cheap admission, which he has found to work so satisfactorily.
He has now plunged into the higher responsibilities of

A SPANISH ROLLA-KING PERUVIAN DRAMA
T h e success w h i c h u s u a l l y a t t e n d s a w e l l - w r i t t e n and well acted Burlesque
c a n leave no doubt t h a t public taste approves t h a t description of e n t e r t a i n m e n t .
I n compliance, t h e r e f o r e , w i t h an opinion of m y o w n . and a suggestion of t h e
Author, w e have sought for a fresh c h a p t e r in t h e pages- of Bombast w h i c h m a y
combine w i t h t h e revival of a P l a y appertaining to a period of great interest and
little principle m u c h that is undoubtedly novel and amusing:.
Heretofore the subjects have been chosen from t h e creation of one Mr. W i l l i a m
S h a k e s p e a r e ; in t h e present instance I have selected t h e w e l l - k n o w n D r a m a of
P I Z A R R O , for t h e purpose of exemplifying m a n y of t h e performances a n d
exhibitions of P e r u , at t h e time w h e n t h e people found out that t h e Spaniards
w e r e d o w n upon 'em. T h e discovery of t h e W e s t e r n H e m i s p h e r e by K i t t y
Columbus, ( p e r h a p s t h e most hairbrained
exhibition of t h e great lengths t o
w h i c h a d v e n t u r e r s w i l l sometimes go *n t h e a n n a l s of commercial enterprise.)
opened a wa» to a good m a n y places »tpto that time u n k n o w n , and n u m e r o u s
successors of t h e illustrious pioneer p e n e t r a t e ' region after region of t h e vast
continent, c ager in t h e s e a r c h of w h a t the>y could get.
E u r o p e received t h e startling intelligence, "by our o w n Correspondent.'*
t h a t Mexico a n d P e r u teemed w i t h millions of all sorts, and no end of gold fields.
W h i l e Nature a p p e a r e d to revel in various w a y s , according to the aspect you
took of her, t h e land abounded w i t h precious gems and metals to such an extent,
t h a t t h e gold w a s actually trodden under foot in t h e dust. It w a s this discovery
t h a t originated the well k n o w n behest, so often mn.de and so seldom complied
w i t h , of "Come d o w n w i t h t h e d u s t . " Indeed it i*i believed that t h e streets of
t h e city of P e r u would have been paved w i t h gold, but that t h e people at t h e time
©f t h e d r a m a w e r e above t h e w e a k n e s s of pavements of a n y k i n d . In placing
upon t h e stage former spectacles, I have availed myself of anybody's discoveries
t h a t w e r e a p p r o p r i a t e , and have laid m y hands upon any t h i n s useful I could
get. I have adopted precisely t h e same course on the present occasion.
B y t h e recent excavations in Assyria, all sorts of mummies w e r e discovered,
w h i l e t h r o u g h t h e adventurous and unscrupulous spirit of t h e Spaniards in t h e
l O t h c e n t u r y , vast nations w e r e pillaged and plundered to a n extent w h i c h only
a r a i l w a y or a b a n k director, w h o has unlimited control of t h e f i n d s , can have
a n y notion of. W e r e a d , w i t h o u t t h e slightest s u r p r i s e , w h o l e nations Of doing
t h e best t h e y could for themselves, and enjoying t h e i r t h e a t r e s , and other evening e n t e r t a i n m e n t s .
I n adapting t h e selected play to t h e purpose of amusing illustration, short cuts
h a v e been made with certain passages, and as the whole piece r e l a t e s to tear,
t h e dialogue has been a r r a n g e d in a p p r o p r i a t e lines. In adopting this c o u r s e ,
I iiave ventured to introdnce m a n y effects w h i c h a r e not to be found in t h e
original drama—for instance, t h e d o n k e y c h a r g e r of* Pliearro. called in t h e original . l e r u s a l e m o k e . has been most unaccountably left behind t h e scenes In t h e
German version. I did t h i n k of introducing t h e tirand Festival of R a m o Samee,
t h e celebrated Indian k n i f e - s w a l l o w e r ; but as no dagger-swaUower could be
obtained a t so short a notice, and as p e r h a p s t h e audience w o u l d not s w a l l o w
t h e c e r e m o n y without, I have I t h i n k judiciously left it alone.
As w e possess no information respecting Quito, f t h e place named by t h e
d r a m a t i s t ) I do not intend to give a n y . I n order however to r e p r e s e n t it a c c u r a t e l y . I have directed t h e scenic artist to paint another place*
T h e Music throughout t h e piece has been a r r a n g e d , w h e n in his moments of
composure, b y H e r r ANSCHLEZ T h e various a i r s a r e founded on melodies i n
t h e "Trovatore,"
and other operas not alluded to in P e r u v i a n antiquities,
although t h e y have extensively been lauded in modern c r i t i q u e s .
By t h e production of P I Z A R R O , long k n o w n as a most bombastic play, I cannot but t h i n k t h a t a w i d e field is afforded for t h e introduction of (hat k i n d of writ
a n d fun, w h i c h Of lote y e a r s has lent a n e w interest to t h e a t r i c a l a r t . T h e p r e sent age d e m a n d s t h a t ail d r a m a t i c representations should have scenery, dresses
a n d music, because people w o u l d n ' t go to see them without. T h e public voice
has justified m e in deciding that historical t r u t h is not ot m u c h consequence,
w h e r e fun and amusement a r e concerned. Hence I conclude, t h a t w h e n an a p p r o p r i a t e opportunity occurs of blending fun w i t h good humour, w h e n t h e mind
c a n be r e l a x e d w h i l e t h e eye t w i n k l e s w i t h delight, I am not likely to lose b y
t h e effort I h a v e m a d e .
I m a y , in conclusion, state t h a t P I Z A R R O , at l i r u r y Lane, is got up w i t h a
d u e disregard to historical a c c u r a c y .

A SPANISH U L U - U K PERUVIAN DRAMA!
The Scenery being in Peru, it is necessary that it should appear who did it; it will, however probably be sufficiently satisfactory to the permet to say that the Lessee has gone to T I N T It R E L L O C L A U D E L O R R A I N . E s q . ,
who having made the ascent of the highest ladder in the Brife,ii "iviuseum, in order to obtain a correct impression of Peruvian
Scenery and having communicated his views general!';, and particularly on the subject, to M e s s r s . W I L S O N a n d
a host Of A s s i s t a n t s , they have under his superintendence executed the most eleborate work of art.
The .Dresses have been prepared under the eyes of M r . J . P A L M E R and M i S S D I C K E N S O N , who in regard
to co-it, you maybe sure have not spared the spangles. The Overture and Music, which will jump "from grave to gay, from
lively to all serene," have been produced, in bis moments of composure, by H e r r A N S C H U E Z , who, spite of his
name, to the Roman owes nothing. The Warriors who perform the War Dance in the Temple of the Sua are under the
immediate command and direction of M o n s . P E T I T , who, spite of his name, is a general in this particular. The
Machinery, which for once has no trap in it, is the result of the machinations of M r , J . T U C K E R ,
The Appointment, :i* all Dramas and especially Burlesques need'em, have been the produce of N E E D H A M .
Perruquier, who
is mPeni qwr of course, M r . R I K . A R D E S .

THE PRODUCTION OF

T H E ANNOUNCED N O V E L T Y !
H » » o r i g i n a t e d f r o m t h e r e c e i p t o f t h e a n n e x e d Letter,
addressed
t . t h e Manager of t h i . Theatret-*
" Bedfoid Street, Covent Garden,—Jan. 25th, 1838.'
"SIR
Being a lone stranger in this animated wilderness, London! I am
nnder the necessity of introducing myself to yom notice, with the hope that your
good nature will pardon a Tyro's ambition, should it even o'er-vault his discretion.
I bear t h e name, and am veritably a d e f e n d a n t of the Family of WILLIAM
8HAKSFEARE, of the Elizabethan era,"'«« Poet for ail time t"—bnt" ww* *» a""*'*"
I have written two Dramas, one of which I wish to have performed Immediately, and to personate the hero, myself j—I wrote it for the express purpose. All
I ask of yon, is to hear me read my Drama, and if you like it, I will submit to the
more irksome ordeal of acting a Scene before yourself and critical Colleagues, if
you then think that I have merit, favor me with your patronage and rappott-bot
n you decide that I am an impostor, dismiss me with the contempt which I shall
than deserve.
Anxiously waiting your reply, I am, Sir. your humble servant,
WILLIAM SHAKSPEARS.
T h e M a n a g e m e n t , d e s i r o u s to c a t e r N o v e l t y for t h e P u b l i c g r a t i A c a *
ticm. effected a n I n t e r v i e w w i t h t h e W r i t e r o f t h e L e t t e r , t h e r e s u l t
o f w h i c h is—that a n E n g a g e m e n t h a s b e e n e n t e r e d i n t o . a n d - .

This Evening:, SATURDAY. JULY 14th, 1899,

PERIOD IT28.

Mr, W E B S T E R , Lessee or t h e *• Little Theatre in the Hay-market.*
respect tall-.' offers, tor t h e encouragement of Dramatic Literature in thi#
Country, the above sum for the best PROSE COMEDV, in 5 Acts, illus.
r a t i . e . in plot and character, oi modern British Manners and Customs.
rhe merit of tlie Comedy to l»e decided hy a Committee.aiter Monday, J a n .
1, IS44U composed of Hramatic Authors, (not competitors.) Dramatic
Critics, and Actors (male and female) to be named by Mr. W e b s t e r ! and
f i r . Webster to have the casting vote, If required. T h e Comedies to be
ami in anonymously, w i t h a motto. Tlie F I V E HUNDRED POINDS to
he paid immediately on the jinal decision of the Committee, w i t h t h e
advantage of a clear third of the gross receipt*, on the 3 0 t h , 4 0 t h , smtl
DOth Nights of Representation. Further arrangements to be regulated by
the Committee.
